reviewText: Although not the best MST/Rifftrax shorts, still funny and enjoyable for the fans of Shorts. There are 8 Shorts:American Thrift-Shop wisely, save your money and buy a Chevy.Story of a Drug Addict-Shop wisely, save your money and buy drugs.Your Chance to LiveMr. Moto takes a Walk-Monkey on a leash learning the alphabet at the zoo.Kittens:Birth and Growth- Awwwwwwwwwww!Summer is an AdventureReading Growth:Basic SkillsThe Parts of Speech-Much more interesting than English class.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This great DVD features 8 shorts which were all totally hysterically funny! It is funny in the fact too these shorts were meant to be taken seriously. That in itself it worth the purchase price, but the talented Mike, Kevin and Bill make these a masterpiece just waiting for you to enjoy! Invite some company to watch these!!
summary: Awesome shorts to add to your Rifftrax collection!

reviewText: Mike Nelson and the gang have fun riffing on a whole series of education films, everything from the benefits of reading to the zoo to thrift (or home economics. I'm still not sure). Plenty of laughs in this set.

reviewText: For completists only-- but we are legion. Aside from the short about the zoo, the laffs were few and far between. They don't all have to be ROFLers but c'mon guys, people are paying money to watch these... Maybe scale back the number of releases and work a little more magic on what you are putting out.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Rifftrax brings their brand of humor to 8 more short films, which are so bad and so perfect for the guys."American Thrift" starts off showing how the women of America were so important to families staying together, then the film goes into showing a whole bunch of technology from the 50's/early 60's. Its very long, but pretty funny and the guys just seemed to get more and more vicious with their jokes as it went on, which was quite funny."Story of a Teenage Drug Addict", a young man gets hooked on drugs, gets clean, gets hooked again then decides to get clean for good. Thats the story folks, thank goodness Mike and the guys make this one easy to watch as its pretty bad."Your Chance To Live", shows that if you don't appreciate technology and if you abuse it, that many bad things will happen. Its another one that just wanders, but that doesn't stop the jokes from being quite hilarious."Mr. Moto Takes a Walk", a woman is walking around with a monkey on a leash aka Mr. Moto, who escapes and visits various animals in a zoo, all the while the woman provides narration about the animals as she goes through the alphabet. Its very funny as they rip on everything and their are many hilarious parts."Kitten: Birth and Growth", the family cat has kittens and the children helps raise them, its cheesy but it is cute cause of the kittens. The jokes are good, as usual."Summer is an Adventure", in the early 60's a family goes to a relatives cabin by the lake and they have many adventures such as in a speedboat and camping out by a campfire. Boy is this bad, but the jokes are very good."Reading Growth: Basic Skills", how kids learn to read and how their skills grow as they get older. Its so bad but they make it very funny and easy to stomach."The Parts of Speech", we see a few kids playing catch with a beach ball on a beach, while some idiot narrator talks about how nouns and pronouns can be used to describe everyday life. The guys have a blast here destroying everything in this short.Its a funny collection of shorts, I was in stitches a lot of the time.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Another set of short films that haven't seen the light of day for decades - and for good reason.  There is one repeat here though that I found - "Your Chance to Live" was on an earlier set.  I would have given this 4 stars because of that, but the other shorts are so well done that I overlooked their error.The short "American Thrift" starts this off and goes all over the place.  They needed a roadmap and GPS to get back to the subject at hand.  And the rest?  Mr. Moto Takes A Walk.  Damn monkey - I would have fed it to the lions.  And there are stories about teenage drug addicts played by non-professionals (no kidding!) who looks like they graduated college or at least got paroled from the big house, as well as some story about reading, and if you are an English teacher, at least you will enjoy The Parts of Speech.  There are other stories, but just go ahead and get this to see for yourself.
summary: Another great set from Mike, Kevin and Bill
Title: N/A

reviewText: Of all the efforts from the Rifftrax folks I like the short subjects best. I am a diehard fan of MST3K, Rifftrax, and Cinematic Titanic, and it pains me to give any effort from Bill Corbett, Mike Nelson, and Kevin Murphy anything but five stars, but sadly in this case it's warranted. Unlike most of the Rifftrax shorts collections, "Order in the Shorts" is only sporadically amusing, suffered from middling subject matter, and featured a couple of unwelcome distractions.None of the shorts absolutely thrilled me as a great choice except "Your Chance to Live," and a couple of them suffered from being excessively long and bored me to tears, especially "American Thrift," "Summer in an Adventure," and "The Parts of Speech." The set begins with "American Thrift," and features special guest voice artist Veronica Belmont for the first half of the short (before the intermission.) I didn't find the short to be especially entertaining, and it was a similar subject to earlier Rifftrax efforts; further the presence of Belmont was distracting at best. "Summer is an Adventure" is another plodding effort which chronicles the fun of summer in the style of silent home movies from the 1960s: the riffing tried hard, but nothing could save this footage from being excruciatingly dull. It's better left unwatched. "The Parts of Speech" is a good basic grammar review set on a beach. The beach sounds like it would make the grammar more bearable, but don't be fooled: grammar can be a powerfully boring subject. "Story of a Teenage Drug Addict" is a lengthy and painful juvenile delinquent drug use educational short like many (many) other similar films made. It reminded me stylistically of a shorter, more boring, and less funny version of "I Accuse My Parents."There were good points in the collection, too. "Mr. Moto Takes a Walk" is a bizarre walk through a zoo in alphabetical order with a pretty girl and her monkey. This one was original and funny. Wait for the shocking revelation about the letter "X." "Kittens: Birth and Growth" was amusing and is kind of like a prequel to "Kitty Cleans Up," one of the greatest of all Rifftrax shorts. Best of all is "Your Chance to Live," a meandering, confusing film about technology. It's another of the Rifftrax greats. Unfortunately, it is also in an earlier Rifftrax shorts collection. I am unsure why it reappeared here, but I felt a bit cheated to find inexplicably repeated material on this new DVD.I love Rifftrax and hold Bill, Mike, and Kevin in the highest regard comedically, but this is not one of their better efforts. If you are an MST3K or Rifftrax fan, by all means get the disc; if you're new to these efforts, there are much better sets to start with.
summary: A Mundane Effort From Riffing Superstars

reviewText: Order In The Shorts is a 124 minutes of solid riffing from Mike Nelson, Kevin Murphy and Bill Corbett, formerly of Mystery Science Theater 3000. Shorts include:- American Thrift. Learn to be thrifty from a bygone time when it was a lot easier to do so.- Story Of A Teenager Drug Addict. The point about the dangers of heroin addiction is well made, albeit in dull black-and-white fashion even less exciting than Reefer Madness.- Your Chance To Live. This odd short focusing on technology failures never seems to decide what point it is trying to make at all.- Mr. Moto Takes A Walk. The alphabetic adventures of a pet monkey and his owner at a zoo.- Kittens: Birth And Growth. Watch kittens being born and grow a bit. It's riveting if you're perhaps seven years of age or less.- Summer Is An Adventure. What someone else did on their summer vacation. About as exciting as someone else's home movies.- Reading Growth: Basic Skills. If you need remedial reading, this is your short.- The Parts Of Speech. Grammar lessons made more exciting by turning them into a film about grammar.The shorts themselves are light and tepid fare made quite watchable by the hilarious Rifftrax commentary track. At more than 2 hours running time this collection is great comedy bargain.
summary: Eight shorts and more than two hours of laughs
Title: N/A
